name: carex
wildlife-value: Seeds are a food source for small mammals, ducks, grouse, wild turkeys, songbirds.  Larval food source for caterpillars.  The leaves provide cover and nestings sites.
light: Deep shade (Less than 2 hours to no direct sunlight)
Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: A dry, one-seeded indehiscent nutlet, sometimes trifolate.
flower-description: Solitary or dense spiklets appear spring to early summer. The defining structure of the genus Carex is the bottle-shaped bract surrounding each female flower containing a the single seeded fruit.
leaf-description: Leaves are composed of a blade, which extends away from the stalk, and a sheath, which encloses part of the stalk. The blade is normally long and flat, but may be folded or absent. The leaves have parallel veins and a distinct midrib and triangular clums. Foliage may be green, red or brown.
uses: Sedges have been used for weaving baskets.
